attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

metadata.value: Ilyas, Mansur ibn Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yusef ibn
metadata.label: Creator

metadata.value: Detail of coloured anatomical drawing of the body, with handwritten labels. Major orans such as the heart, kidneys and intestines can be seen. From Mansur's Anatomy, also known as Tashrih-I Mansuri, a treatise on the five "systems" of the body: bones, nerves, muscles, veins and arteries. Written in both Persian and Arabic, in the Nasta'liq script, the book has a chapter on each of these sections, as well as an introduction and an appendix on the formation of the foetus and organs. The manuscript has one hundred folios containing numerous illustrations and is 12 inches by 7 ¼ inches in size. It is not dated but is thought to have been created at some point during the 19th century. However, the original dates to c.1400. Sources: Hukk, M (1925), A descriptive catalogue of the Arabic and Persian manuscripts in Edinburgh University Library, Hertford. http://www.nlm.nih.gov/exhibition/historicalanatomies/mansur_bio.html (accessed 13/06/14).
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Ilyas, Mansur ibn Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yusef ibn
metadata.label: Creator

metadata.value: Detail of two coloured anatomical illustrations. The example on the right appears to show veins or nerves and has been labelled by hand, while the image on the right shows the major organs, such as the heart and kidneys. From Mansur's Anatomy, also known as Tashrih-I Mansuri, a treatise on the five "systems" of the body: bones, nerves, muscles, veins and arteries. Written in both Persian and Arabic, in the Nasta'liq script, the book has a chapter on each of these sections, as well as an introduction and an appendix on the formation of the foetus and organs. The manuscript has one hundred folios containing numerous illustrations and is 12 inches by 7 ¼ inches in size. It is not dated but is thought to have been created at some point during the 19th century. However, the original dates to c.1400. Sources: Hukk, M (1925), A descriptive catalogue of the Arabic and Persian manuscripts in Edinburgh University Library, Hertford. http://www.nlm.nih.gov/exhibition/historicalanatomies/mansur_bio.html (accessed 13/06/14).
